Like Jim Carrey said: DO NOT GO IN THERE!

Change is hard and of course there are things you can do to get the water warm, but if you have been avoiding your child’s big feelings by taking over bedtime routine any time they show they’re upset with your partner, then you can definitely expect that those big feelings are going to come out once you eliminate yourself from the equation.

I am a very pull off the Band-Aid type person, but if you have an older infant or a toddler, it can always help to communicate in advance. I like to tell them, “I know you want mommy to do bedtime, but tonight, [your partner] is going to do it!”

As I mentioned in the video, you could also have your child choose specific days of the week where your partner is in charge of bedtime, and you could also have your partner gradually get themselves involved in the bedtime process by taking over one task at a time. However, even with that, it’s normal for there to be a period of adjustment once your partner takes over. 

Of course you guys should have a game plan in advance (any non negotiable like, if you have been making progress with not lying in bed with your child until they fall asleep, that should be the one boundary that your partner holds), but during the process, let your partner figure out ways to regulate your child on their own, without your involvement. And for those of you who are stressed out about the timing of bedtime and just want to rush things along, go into this expecting that it’s going to take longer than usual to begin with.

Consistency is key here, so know that it might be hard before it gets “normal” (I would say “easy,” let’s be real, you’re still putting a kid to bed at the end of a long day…nothing is easy anymore).

If you aren’t even in this realm and you are experiencing bigger issues like your child waking up constantly in the night, you being unable to leave their room, you wanting to transition them into their own sleep space, I have my Tackling Toddler Sleep Course at TacklingToddlerSleep.com!
